page.title: 02Forestry
page.content: Woodland in the area amounts to roughly 100 acres. The largest plantations are in the N.W. corner where 15 year old Larch and Scotspine are bordered by natural Sycamore, Alder and Birch. South of the river, at Norbury, most of the planting has been within the last 30 years, a mixture of soft woods, oak, beech and ash. After final thinning hardwoods will predominate. Opposite Church Mayfield Beech and softwoods stand above the river. Hedgerow trees are plentiful owing to the small size of the fields. Oak and ash being the most common. The Elms are all gone since the advent of Dutch Elm disease ten years ago. Hawthorn and Damson are plentiful, the fruit of the latter once being sold for dye to the Mills in the Churnet valley.
